I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has actively supported trade since the 1990s and 
now more actively in line with the regional cooperation objectives of its Strategy 20201 and the 
regional  cooperation  and  integration  strategy  adopted  in  2006,2 which  identified  trade  and 
investment as one of the four pillars (pillar 2). Various ADB-supported subregional programs—
the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation,  Greater  Mekong  Subregion,  South  Asia 
Subregional Economic Cooperation, and Pacific Islands Forum—identify the facilitation of cross-
border trade processes as a key component in furthering trade expansion within the subregions. 
The recently approved Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–20203 
reaffirms  ADB‘s  support  for  trade  facilitation  under  the  three  outcome-focused  operational 
directions: connectivity, competitiveness, and regional common goods. 
 
2.   At the same time, ADB has actively promoted good practices in trade facilitation through 
a series of partnerships with other international organizations.4  ADB’s partnership with the 
World Customs Organization has helped developing member countries (DMCs) improve their 
customs procedures.5 The partnership with the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and 
the Pacific (ESCAP) has provided ADB’s DMCs a platform for sharing knowledge on trade 
facilitation  challenges  and  experiences  at  the  regional  level.6 Based  on  the  lessons  and 
recommendations  from  past  ADB  projects,  the  ADB  Management’s  response  to  the 
Independent Evaluation Department’s thematic evaluation study on regional cooperation and 
integration, and the partnership memorandum of understanding between ADB and ESCAP, the 
technical assistance (TA) will continue to support trade facilitation in the region, particularly the 
Asia-Pacific Trade Facilitation Forum (APTFF).7 The APTFF has built the capacities of over 
1,000 DMC officials since 2009 and has launched knowledge products to guide the design, 
implementation, and monitoring of trade facilitation.8 The design and monitoring framework is in

II.  ISSUES 
3.  Increased international trade has largely benefited from major improvements through 
reduction in tariffs and nontariff barriers. Tariffs, both in most favored nation and free trade 
agreement rates, have been going down in Asia. Nontariff barriers, however, continue to impede 
smooth transactions in trade.10 For example, significant costs to international trade remain due 
to complex customs and at-the-border procedures. Moreover, the progress of trade facilitation 
reforms significantly varies across economies as well as subregions. In particular, land-locked 
and sea-locked countries are facing serious obstacles to trade from the lack of integrated border 
management, as well as cross-border trade facilitation coordination, which are exacerbated by 
their particular geographic circumstances that add trade cost.  With the general decline in tariffs, 
the private sector has shifted its focus from tariffs to reducing transport and transaction costs, 
along with other nontariff barriers. The gains from trade facilitation will surpass the benefits from 
further tariff reduction, with developing countries likely to benefit the most.11 
 
4.  Meanwhile, international trade has undergone a transformation and a new landscape 
has emerged, characterized by vast improvement in maritime and air shipping brought about by 
technological advancement and cooperation among economies. Just-in-time delivery and low 
inventory retention, multimodal logistics services, and the increasing complexity of supply chain 
networks  have  increasingly  added  cumulative  pressures  to  border  operations  across  Asia. 
These developments and changes have underscored the important role of trade facilitation and 
have required relevant border management administrations to strengthen their capacities to 
carry out greater responsibilities and extended functions.12 
 
5.  To respond to demand from the stakeholders and meet the challenges facing developing 
countries in the region, on 24 April 2015, ADB and ESCAP extended their memorandum of 
understanding until the end of 2020, reaffirming their desire to work together in areas of mutual 
interest in the service of the developing countries in the region. In addition, in the 11th annual 
consultation  meeting  between  ADB  and  ESCAP  conducted  on  12  November  2015,  they 
acknowledged the achievements made on trade facilitation and committed to continue their 
support for regional integration and connectivity as one of the four joint priority cooperation 
areas with trade facilitation and paperless trade (technology and innovation) as core programs. 
 
6.  In the Support for Trade Facilitation TA, which concluded in March 2016, participants 
noted  the  relevance,  knowledge  learned,  and  usefulness  of  the  APTFF  to  their  roles  in 
formulating, implementing, and monitoring trade and trade facilitation policies. The participants 
also recommended ADB’s continued support to the APTFF as well as the expansion and 
deepening of ADB’s research work on trade facilitation.13 This TA will further enhance the

III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7  The impact will be increase in the region’s trade volume. The outcome will be improved 
policies and practices on trade facilitation. The outcome will be measured through the number of 
trade facilitation measures that are initiated or implemented in some DMCs, the information for 
which will be obtained through a survey during the forums.14  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The  TA  will  support  the  conduct  of  two  APTFFs  and  one  roundtable  meeting, 
enhancement of trade negotiation and trade facilitation policy formulation and implementation 
skills of DMC officials, and publication and dissemination of a research study report on the 
economic  impact  assessment  of  trade  facilitation  especially  in  terms  of  quantification  and 
improvement of progress monitoring. 
 
9.  Output 1: Asia-Pacific Trade Facilitation Forums successfully conducted in 2017 
and  2019.  The APTFFs will be held in 2017 and 2019, with the objectives of (i) sharing 
experiences  and  knowledge  between  and  among  countries  in  the  region;  (ii)  increasing 
understanding and exchange of views between public and private stakeholders, as well as with 
trade facilitation standard developers and technical assistance providers; (iii) sharing lessons 
from ongoing implementation of the national and regional trade facilitation measures; and (iv) 
developing  relevant  international  tools,  instruments,  and  facilities  aimed  at  increasing  the 
efficiency of regional and global trade.  
 
10.  Output  2:  Roundtable  meeting  successfully  conducted  in  2018. The roundtable 
meeting in 2018 is envisioned to be a bridge event between the two APTFFs with the objective 
of providing a venue for key government officials to discuss actions pursued immediately after 
the APTFF in 2017, deliberate on crucial trade policy issues, keep the momentum of trade 
facilitation going, and monitor progress on trade facilitation initiatives.  
 
11.  Output  3:  Trade  negotiation  and  trade  facilitation  policy  formulation  and 
implementation skills of developing member country officials enhanced. ADB will partner 
with knowledge institutions specialized on trade to further build the capacities of selected DMC 
officials for handling trade negotiations, trade facilitation, and other matters related to trade. 
Detailed criteria for partnership with knowledge institutions and selection of DMC officials will be 
prepared in consultation with ADB’s regional departments and ESCAP. Specific training needs 
of DMCs as identified from existing ADB projects will be discussed with regional departments. 
12.  Output 4: Research study report published and disseminated. The research on the 
impact of trade facilitation will be based on self-contained background papers.15  The TA will

assess the progress of trade facilitation reforms in the region through trade cost indicators and 
measure the potential impact of trade facilitation on outcomes such as trade, foreign direct 
investment, growth, and poverty. Most previous research on the quantification of benefits of 
trade facilitation has focused exclusively on the impact on gross domestic product growth.16 
More comprehensive studies on the economic impact assessment have been requested by the 
regional departments during previous consultations with the Economic Research and Regional 
Coordination Department, pointing to the relevance of such research to ADB operations. The 
key findings of the research will be shared with regional departments for possible pilot-testing 
and disseminated through the APTFF and ADB publications like the Asian Economic Integration 
Report.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The detailed cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2.  
  
14.  For the conduct of the APTFFs, ESCAP will provide and administer funding support 
estimated at $200,000. Selected government hosts will provide administrative support and local 
costs such as meeting packages and study tours which they will also administer themselves.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be executed by ADB and implemented by the Economic Research and 
Regional Cooperation Department. The Office of the Chief Economist and Director General will 
handle the overall administration and supervision of the TA and at the same time lead the 
delivery of the trade facilitation forums, including supervision of the consultants who will be hired 
to deliver the APTFFs, roundtable meeting, and training. The Office of the Chief Economist and 
Director General will liaise and coordinate with the ESCAP and the selected government hosts 
for the organization of the forums, consult and coordinate with the regional departments for their 
technical  inputs  and  participation  as  resource  persons,  and  arrange  the  participation  of 
representatives from the DMCs. Experts from ESCAP will also be tapped. To deliver the training, 
partnership with knowledge institutions with a proven track record on providing training on trade-
related matters will be explored along with possibly providing training as a side event during the 
                                                                                                                                                       
subregional programs. In line with recommendations from APTFF 2015, this paper may also include a regional 
overview of trade facilitation at the sector level (in particular in agriculture and services), and the emerging role of 
cross-border  e-commerce.  (ii)  A  second  background  paper  will  carry  out  a  review  of  available  data  and 
methodologies that have been previously employed for the purpose of economic impact assessment, and an 
assessment of the suitability of various approaches in line with ADB operations. These include on one hand macro 
approaches to quantify economy or region-wide impacts such as computable general equilibrium models and 
applied econometric methodologies such as the inverse gravity framework; and on the other hand measurement of 
localized  trade  facilitation  interventions  through  time  release  studies  and  project  assessments.  (iii)  A  third 
background paper will employ a more systematic methodology moving beyond the standard principal component 
analysis for the construction of a trade facilitation index for the monitoring and progress of trade facilitation across 
the ADB-supported subregional programs. (iv) The remaining background papers will involve the economic impact 
assessment of trade facilitation as measured by the specially constructed trade facilitation indicators on foreign 
direct investment, poverty and inequality, and economic growth. (v) A final background paper will outline policy 
implications in light of the economic impact assessment. This paper will also examine how trade facilitation can 
facilitate the Sustainable Development Goals.

APTFF.17 The Regional Cooperation and Integration Division will lead the implementation and 
be responsible for delivering the research study. Consultants for the study will be hired in 
coordination with the Office of the Chief Economist and Director General, but will be supervised 
by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Division. The duration of the TA will be from 
January 2017 to December 2019.  
  
16.  Consultants and resource persons under this TA will be hired individually by ADB and in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). Ten consultants will be hired by the TA individually since collective responsibility is not a 
requirement, additional outside (home office) professional support is not required, and individual 
experience and qualifications are more important. Five international consultants with expertise 
in international trade and its related areas will be hired for the conduct of the research study 
(10 person-months). Two national consultants will be hired as research associates (20 person-
months), one consultant as program coordinator (24 person-months), and two consultants to 
work on the publishing side (3.3 person-months). Eight resource persons will be engaged as 
discussants for the two APTFFs and roundtable meeting (Appendix 3). All disbursements will be 
done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). Lump-sum payments or output-based contracts will be considered 
for consulting services under the TA in line with the action plan for the Midterm Review of 
Strategy 2020.18  
  
17.  Reports from the APTFFs and the roundtable meeting will be uploaded in ADB’s and 
ESCAP’s websites. Training materials will be shared through ADB’s k-learn website and the 
research study report will be disseminated via a “digital-first” approach. In addition, reports on 
the progress of trade facilitation initiatives will be shared with the regional departments. Initial 
findings  of  the  research  study  will  be  presented  in  Economic  Research  and  Regional 
Coordination Department workshops and in the APTFFs. The final research study will also be 
disseminated  through  the  APTFF  network  and  ADB  publications  like  the  Asian  Economic 
Integration Report.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Support for Trade Facilitation in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Trade  economists  (5  consultants,  10  person-months  total,  intermittent).  The 
consultants will be knowledgeable in international trade, international economics, and/or trade 
policy;  preferably  with  5  to  7  years  of  relevant  experience;  and  should  have  extensive 
professional  experience  working  in  government  institutions  and/or  international  financial 
institutions. The consultants should have a master’s degree in economics. A doctorate degree in 
economics, trade, or a related field would be an advantage. Under the guidance of the trade 
specialist of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the consultants will work on the following 
specific areas and do the following: 
 
(i)  Consultant 1: Trade facilitation context in the Asian Development Bank, 
Asia  and  the  Pacific  region,  and  Sustainable  Development  Goals.  The 
consultant  shall  (a)  assess  the  current  situation;  (b)  identify  gaps,  issues, 
challenges, and areas for policy reform; (c) assess possible actions in relation to 
the Sustainable Development Goals; and (d) provide policy recommendations as 
appropriate.   
 
(ii)   Consultant  2:  Survey  of  data  and  methodologies.  The  consultant  shall 
(a) assess the current situation; (b) assess the current level of application; (c) 
identify advantages, gaps, and areas for improvement; and (d) provide policy 
recommendations as appropriate.  
 
(iii)  Consultant  3:  Assess  and  measure  the  progress  in  trade  facilitation 
through  estimation  of  trade  costs  and  construction  of trade facilitation 
index.  The  consultant  shall  (i) assess  the  current  situation;  (ii)  assess 
methodologies in measurement of trade costs and trade facilitation; (iii) develop 
an  appropriate  trade  facilitation  index  or  provide  trade  cost  estimates  or 
equivalent measures; and (iv) test the measure and provide recommendations. 
 
(iv)   Consultants 4 and 5: Economic impact assessments of trade facilitation. 
The consultants shall (a) assess the current situation; (b) gather and analyze 
data; (c) using selected methodologies, provide an economic impact assessment 
on  selected  developing  member  countries;  and  (d)  provide  policy 
recommendations as appropriate.  
 
2.  The consultants will have a regular monthly teleconference or videoconference with the 
supervising ADB specialist to discuss the progress of the paper. The papers will be presented in 
a peer review meeting in ADB prior to finalization.   
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
3.  Research  associates (2 consultants, 20 person-months total, intermittent). National 
consultants will be hired to assist in the research requirements for the study, including data 
handling. The consultants should have a background in economics and strong analytical skills.  
A master’s degree in economics or a related field would be an advantage. Under the guidance 
of ADB’s technical assistance supervising unit, the consultants will 
(i)  collect and analyze study-related data and material, 
(ii)  prepare charts and tables,

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iii)  prepare presentations and publications, 
(iv)  assist in the finalization of the study, and 
(v)  perform other related tasks as required. 
  
4.  The consultants’ outputs are inputs to the study in the form of charts and tables, write-
ups and analysis of specific areas, requested datasets, and presentation materials. 
 
5.  Program coordinator (24 person-months, intermittent). A national consultant will serve 
as  the  coordinator for overall  preparations  in organizing  the  Asia-Pacific Trade  Facilitation 
Forums (APTFFs), the roundtable meetings, and the training programs, including coordinating 
the submission of background papers and the logistic arrangements. The consultant should 
have strong writing skills and extensive experience in handling international events. Knowledge 
of ADB procedures and requirements for technical assistance disbursement and liquidation 
would be an advantage. Under the supervision of staff from ADB’s Office of the Chief Economist 
and Director General, the consultant will be stationed at ADB headquarters in Manila and will 
(i)  support ADB staff and the trade facilitation experts in the organization of the 
APTFFs, the roundtable and the training programs, including liaising with the 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, training institutions, 
and other collaborators on the detailed arrangements; 
(ii)  support logistical requirements for the conduct of the APTFFs, the roundtable, 
and the training, including budget preparation and liquidation; 
(iii)  provide assistance in research relating to the APTFFs, the roundtable, and the 
training programs; 
(iv)  provide both logistic and technical support during the APTFFs, the roundtable 
and the training programs; 
(v)  draft summary proceedings of the APTFFs, the roundtable, the training programs 
and its side events; and other meeting discussions; 
(vi)  assist  in  completing  post-APTFFs,  post-roundtable,  and  post-training  tasks 
related  to  logistic  arrangements  and  coordination  with  the  trade  facilitation 
experts and resource persons;  
(vii)  attend  and  join  ADB  missions  related  to  the  conduct  of  the  APTFFs,  the 
roundtable, and the training programs as necessary; and 
(viii)  other tasks as required. 
 
6.  The consultant’s outputs are the final arrangements for the APTFFs, roundtable meeting, 
and training; supporting liquidation materials; draft summary proceedings or highlights of the 
Forum; and the roundtable meeting. 
 
7.  Copy editor (1.5 person-months). A copy editor will be engaged to ensure that prior to 
publication, reports and the study produced adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high 
publication standards. Ideally, a copy editor from the Department of External Relations pool will 
be hired for specific manuscripts. The consultant should have expertise in copy editing and have 
extensive  experience  in  similar  assignments.  Knowledge  of  ADB’s  Handbook  of  Style  and 
Usage is required. 
 
8.  Desktop publishing specialist (2 person-months). A layout artist and typesetter will be 
hired to layout the text, tables, and charts; and convert the files into the required format for 
publication.  The  consultant  should  have  expertise  in  desktop  publishing  with  extensive 
experience  in  preparing  economic  publications.  Knowledge  of  ADB’s  Branding  Tool  Kit  is 
required.

Appendix 3  11 
9.  Resource  persons (8 resource  persons,  66  person-days total).  Resource  persons, 
whose expertise and knowledge will be specified during implementation, will be engaged to 
serve as discussants, paper writers, and/or presenters. They will work closely with ADB staff, 
the trade facilitation experts, and the program coordinator.
